chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Bene autem apparuit. Revelata est enim Dei [f. Christi] nativitas multis modis. Revelata est per angelos pastoribus; revelata est per stellam regibus.
chunks.english: And he appeared well. For the birth of Christ was revealed in many ways. It was revealed through angels to shepherds; it was revealed through a star to kings.
chunks.notes: Dual revelation: angels and star

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Audivimus enim in Evangelio, quod «pastores erant in regione eadem vigilantes, et custodientes vigilias noctis super gregem suum. Et ecce angelus Domini stetit juxta illos; et timuerunt timore magno. Et dixit eis angelus: Nolite timere. Ecce enim evangelizo vobis gaudium magnum, quod erit omni populo, quia natus est vobis hodie Salvator, qui est Christus Dominus (Luc. II, 8, et seq.).»
chunks.english: For we heard in the Gospel that shepherds were in that same region keeping watch and guarding their flock during the watches of the night. And behold, an angel of the Lord stood beside them, and they feared with great fear. And the angel said to them: Do not be afraid. For behold, I bring you good news of great joy that will be for all the people, for to you is born today a Savior, who is Christ the Lord. This comes from the Gospel of Luke, chapter two, verse eight and following.
chunks.notes: Luke 2:8-11 - angelic announcement to shepherds

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et ubi est natus? «In civitate David,» id est Bethlehem. «Et hoc vobis signum: Invenietis infantem pannis involutum et positum in praesepio. Et subito facta est cum angelo multitudo militiae coelestis exercitus laudantium Deum, et dicentium: Gloria in excelsis Deo, et in terra pax hominibus bonae voluntatis (ibid.).»
chunks.english: And where was he born? In the city of David—that is, Bethlehem. And this will be a sign to you: You will find an infant wrapped in swaddling cloths and lying in a manger. And suddenly there was with the angel a multitude of the heavenly host praising God and saying: Glory to God in the highest, and on earth peace to people of good will. This continues in the same passage.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Hoc audientes pastores venerunt usque Bethlehem, et viderunt sicut dictum fuerat ad illos per angelum.
chunks.english: Hearing this, the shepherds came to Bethlehem and saw just as had been told to them by the angel.

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Merito hoc angelus nuntiavit, quia Rex angelorum natus erat. Et dignum erat ut cum magna luce apparuisset angelus, quia solem justitiae, lumen in tenebris declaravit exortum.
chunks.english: The angel rightly announced this, because the King of angels had been born. And it was fitting that the angel appeared with great light, because he declared that the sun of righteousness, the light shining in darkness, had risen.
chunks.notes: Malachi 4:2; John 1:5 allusions

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Pastoribus nuntiatum est, quia natus est ille qui ait: «Ego sum pastor bonus (Joan. X, 11).»
chunks.english: It was announced to shepherds because he was born who says in the Gospel of John, chapter ten, verse eleven: I am the good shepherd.
chunks.notes: John 10:11 - connection between shepherds as recipients and Christ as Good Shepherd

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Per stellam apparuit regibus, quia ortus erat Rex et stella. Rex, unde scriptum est: «Ego autem costitutus sum Rex ab eo (Psal. II, 6); stella, unde scriptum est: «Orietur stella ex Jacob (Num. XXIV, 17).»
chunks.english: He appeared through a star to kings because one had risen who was both King and Star. King, as it is written in Psalm two, verse six: I have been established as King by him. Star, as it is written in the book of Numbers, chapter twenty-four, verse seventeen: A star shall rise from Jacob.
chunks.notes: Psalm 2:6 and Numbers 24:17

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Merito itaque apparuit pastoribus et regibus, quia ipse erat rex et sacerdos natus de regali et sacerdotali genere. De regali semine, quia de semine David; de sacerdotali, quia Maria cognata Elisabeth erat.
chunks.english: Therefore he rightly appeared to shepherds and kings, because he himself was king and priest, born from royal and priestly lineage. From royal seed, because from the seed of David; from priestly lineage, because Mary was a relative of Elizabeth.
chunks.notes: Christ's dual genealogy as king (Davidic) and priest (Aaronic through Mary's kinship with Elizabeth)

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Satis commendabilis fuit nuntius, quia angelus, et cum magna voce, de qua legitur in Evangelio: «Et erat uxor Zachariae de filiabus Aaron, et nomen ejus Elisabeth (Luc. I, V).»
chunks.english: The messenger was quite commendable—an angel with a great voice, concerning whom it is read in the Gospel according to Luke, chapter one, verse five: Zacharias' wife was from the daughters of Aaron, and her name was Elizabeth.
chunks.notes: Luke 1:5 - Elizabeth's priestly lineage

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sed audite quid attulit: Ecce evangelizo vobis gaudium magnum, quia natus est vobis hodie Salvator. Vere gaudium magnum. Captivi eramus in carcere, jacebamus in infirmitate. Natus est medicus. Ecce gaudium magnum.
chunks.english: But hear what he brought: Behold, I bring you good news of great joy, for to you is born today a Savior. Truly great joy! We were captives in prison, we lay in sickness. A physician has been born. Behold, great joy!
chunks.notes: Metaphors of captivity and sickness healed by Christ the physician

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Multo magis gaudium erat hominibus, cum angeli gauderent, et dicerent: Gloria in excelsis Deo. Gaudium erat apud angelos de restauratione diminuti ordinis. Laudabant Dominum de reparatione hominum, ad restaurationem angelorum.
chunks.english: There was much more joy for humans when the angels rejoiced and said: Glory to God in the highest. There was joy among the angels about the restoration of their diminished order. They praised the Lord for the restoration of humans, which led to the restoration of angels.
chunks.notes: Angels rejoice because human salvation fills the ranks depleted by fallen angels

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Et hominibus est pax, quia discordiam cum Deo et cum angelis habuimus; sed per mediatorem reconciliati sumus.
chunks.english: And there is peace for humans, because we had discord with God and with angels, but through the mediator we have been reconciled.
chunks.notes: Christ as mediator reconciling humanity to God and angels

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Quia peccando extranei eramus, ideo et extraneos nos a suo consortio deputabant angeli. Adeo angeli vilipendebant homines, quod se ab eis adorari permittebant.
chunks.english: Because we were strangers through sin, the angels also considered us strangers from their fellowship. The angels so despised humans that they allowed themselves to be worshiped by them.
chunks.notes: Before Christ, angels accepted human worship due to human degradation

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Hinc est enim, quod Lot et Abraham angelos adorabant, nec ipsi prohibentur ante adventum Christi.
chunks.english: For this is why Lot and Abraham worshiped angels, and they were not forbidden before the advent of Christ.
chunks.notes: Genesis 18-19 examples of patriarchs worshiping angels

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Sed nato Domino, cum Joannes voluit adorare angelum in Apocalypsi, idem angelus ne se debeat adorare compescit, dicens: «Vide ne feceris, conservus tuus sum, et fratrum tuorum (Apoc. XIX, 10).»
chunks.english: But after the Lord was born, when John wished to worship an angel in the book of Revelation, that same angel restrained him from worshiping, saying in chapter nineteen, verse ten: See that you do not do that; I am your fellow servant and of your brothers.
chunks.notes: Revelation 19:10 (also 22:9) - angels now refuse worship after the Incarnation restored human dignity

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Prius naturam humanam despiciebant angeli, ut inferiorem; sed, postquam eam assumptam super se conspiciunt, prostratam sibi videre pertimescunt, nec dedignantur hominem socium, qui super se adorant hominem Deum.
chunks.english: Previously the angels looked down on human nature as inferior. But after they see it assumed above themselves, they fear to see it prostrate before them, nor do they disdain man as a companion—they who worship above themselves the God-man.
chunks.notes: Reversal: angels now see humanity exalted in Christ above themselves

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Pax nuntiatur hominibus, sed non omnibus, imo hominibus bonae voluntatis. Ac si dicerent: Illi reconciliabuntur, qui habent bonam voluntatem reconciliandi. Illi vero habent voluntatem reconciliandi qui vovent se Creatori, nec faciunt contrarium voluntati ejus.
chunks.english: Peace is announced to humans, but not to all—rather, to people of good will. As if to say: Those will be reconciled who have a good will to be reconciled. And those have the will to be reconciled who devote themselves to the Creator and do not act contrary to his will.
chunks.notes: 'Good will' = willingness to be reconciled, not self-generated merit

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: Notandum est quare dixit, bonae voluntatis, et non actionis, quia voluntas bona sufficit, si facultas operationis desit. Itaque bona voluntas valet aliquando, sine operatione bona; operatio vero nunquam sine bona voluntate. Maluit ergo dicere, bonae voluntatis, quod commune est omnibus salvatis.
chunks.english: It should be noted why he said of good will and not of action, because good will suffices if the ability to act is lacking. Thus good will sometimes avails without good action, but action never avails without good will. Therefore he preferred to say of good will, which is common to all who are saved.
chunks.notes: Important pastoral note: good will counts even when circumstances prevent good works; but works without good will are worthless

chunks.speaker: narrator
chunks.latin: natus est Christus, non aperta porta Virginis, quae virgo ante partum, virgo in partu, virgo post partum. De hac porta Virginis dixit Dominus ad Ezechielem: «Porta haec quam vides, clausa erit, et non aperietur, et vir non intrabit per eam (Ezech. XLIV, 2),» quam ingressus est Dominus Deus Israel, et semper erit clausa. Magnum meritum, magnum donum, magna gratia! Ancilla peperit Dominum; creatura Creatorem, filia patrem, filia divinitatis, mater humanitatis. Duas nativitates Domini accepimus, unam divinam, alteram humanam. Illam sine matre, istam sine patre. Hodie, fratres charissimi, celebramus temporalem nativitatem propter nos acceptam. Gaudeamus propter reparationem nostram. Hodie suscepit infirmus sanitatem, hodie captivus libertatem, hodie recuperavit exsul haereditatem. Suscipiamus ergo hodie Regem venientem, praeparemus ei habitacula pectorum contra talem imperatorem, ut nos dignetur suscipere, in coelesti Jerusalem, qui vivit et regnat per omnia saecula saeculorum. Amen.
chunks.english: Christ was born without opening the gate of the Virgin, who remained a virgin before giving birth, a virgin during birth, and a virgin after birth. Concerning this gate of the Virgin, the Lord spoke to Ezekiel, saying, "This gate that you see shall remain closed and shall not be opened, and no man shall enter through it," as we read in the book of Ezekiel, chapter forty-four, verse two. The Lord God of Israel entered through it, and it will remain closed forever. What great merit, what great gift, what great grace! The handmaid gave birth to the Lord; the creature bore the Creator; the daughter bore her father; the daughter of divinity became the mother of humanity. We acknowledge two births of the Lord: one divine, the other human. The first was without a mother, the second without a father. Today, dearest brothers and sisters, we celebrate his birth in time, which he accepted for our sake. Let us rejoice because of our restoration. Today the sick person has received health, today the captive has received freedom, today the exile has recovered his inheritance. So let us today receive the King who comes. Let us prepare dwellings in our hearts for such an emperor, that he may graciously receive us into the heavenly Jerusalem, who lives and reigns forever and ever. Amen.
chunks.notes: The sermon emphasizes Mary's perpetual virginity using the image of the closed gate from Ezekiel as a theological type. The rhetorical structure uses parallelism (hodie...hodie...hodie) for emphasis in oral delivery. The phrase 'habitacula pectorum' (dwellings of hearts) has been rendered idiomatically as 'dwellings in our hearts' for natural English flow.
